content:
If you're looking to start a Substack publication with low effort that centers around fiction writing, here are some ideas:

1. Flash Fiction: Write and send short stories of 500 words or less as a weekly or bi-weekly email. You can experiment with different genres, themes, and characters.
2. Serialized Novella: Write a novella and send it out in serialized form, one chapter at a time, to your subscribers. You can build anticipation and keep readers engaged by leaving each chapter on a cliffhanger.
3. Character Profiles: Write in-depth profiles of your fictional characters and send them as a weekly email. You can delve into their backstory, personality, motivations, and relationships.
4. Writing Prompts: Send out a weekly writing prompt to your subscribers, along with an example of your own story. You can encourage your subscribers to write their own stories based on the prompt and share them with you.
5. Dialogue Only Stories: Write and send short stories that are comprised only of dialogue, without any description or narration. This can be an interesting exercise in character development and dialogue writing.
6. Fictional Letters: Write letters from your fictional characters to each other or to an outside recipient and send them as a weekly email. This can be a unique way to showcase your characters' personalities and relationships.
7. Choose Your Own Adventure: Write a choose your own adventure story and send it out in serialized form, with readers choosing the direction of the story. This can be a fun and interactive way to engage with your readers.
8. Short Story Analysis: Choose a published short story and send out an analysis of it, along with your own short story that is inspired by it. This can be a way to explore different writing styles and techniques.
9. Fan Fiction: Write and send fan fiction based on a popular book, movie, or TV show. This can be a fun and low-stakes way to experiment with different characters and settings.
10. Collaborative Fiction: Write a story with your subscribers by sending out a prompt and inviting them to contribute to the story. This can be a unique and interactive way to build a community around your fiction writing.
